title:
Dynamic multi-phase partitioning of decamethylcyclopentasiloxane (D5) in river
water
abstract:
The behaviour of decamethylcyclopentasiloxane (D5) in river water was evaluated
by measuring concentration changes in open beakers. Effective values for the
partition coefficient between organic carbon and water (K) were derived by
least-squares optimisation of a dynamic model which accounted for partitioning
between the sorbed and dissolved phases of D5, and for losses via volatilisation
and hydrolysis. Partial mass transfer coefficients for volatilisation were
derived from model fits to controls containing deionised water. Effective values
of log (K) were between 5.8 and 6.33 (mean 6.16). These figures are higher than
some other experimentally-derived values but much lower than those estimated
from the octanol: water partition coefficient using single-parameter linear free
energy relationships (LFERs). A poly-parameter LFER gave a predicted log (K) of
5.5. Differences in partitioning are believed to be due to the nature of the
organic matter present. The new value for effective K was employed in a simple
model of D5 behaviour in rivers to ascertain the extent to which a higher
affinity for organic carbon would depress volatility. The results suggest that
despite the revised K value, volatilisation of D5 remains a significant removal
mechanism in surface waters. © 2010 Elsevier Lt

Title: Dynamic multi-phase partitioning of decamethylcyclopentasiloxane (D5) in river
water
Authors: M.J. Whelan, R. van Egmond, D. Gore, D. Sanders
PII: S0043-1354(10)00282-4

Dynamic multi-phase partitioning of 2 
decamethylcyclopentasiloxane (D5) in river water 3 
 4 
M.J. Whelan1*, R. van Egmond2, D. Gore2 and D. Sanders2  5 
 6

Abstract 21 
The behaviour of decamethylcyclopentasiloxane (D5) in river water was evaluated by 22 
measuring concentration changes in open beakers. Effective values for the partition 23 
coefficient between organic carbon and water (KOC) were derived by least-squares 24 
optimisation of a dynamic model which accounted for partitioning between the sorbed 25 
and dissolved phases of D5, and for losses via volatilisation and hydrolysis.  Partial 26 
mass transfer coefficients for volatilisation were derived from model fits to controls 27 
containing deionised water. Effective values of log (KOC) were between 5.8 and 6.33 28 
(mean 6.16).  These figures are higher than some other experimentally-derived values 29 
but much lower than those estimated from the octanol : water partition coefficient 30 
using single-parameter linear free energy relationships (LFERs).  A poly-parameter 31 
LFER gave a predicted log (KOC) of 5.5.  Differences in partitioning are believed to be 32 
due to the nature of the organic matter present.  The new value for effective KOC was 33 
employed in a simple model of D5 behaviour in rivers to ascertain the extent to which 34 
a higher affinity for organic carbon would depress volatility.  The results suggest that 35 
despite the revised KOC value, volatilisation of D5 remains a significant removal 36 
mechanism in surface waters. 37 
 38 
 39 
Key Words: Decamethylcyclopentasiloxane, D5, volatilisation, river water, KOC 40 
M

 3 
 41 
Introduction 42 
 43 
Cyclic volatile methyl siloxanes (cVMS) possess an unusual combination of physico-44 
chemical properties, including both hydrophobicity and volatility.  Recently, concerns 45 
have been raised about their environmental profile (Brooke et al., 2008) because they 46 
have relatively high bioconcentration factors, implying some potential for 47 
bioaccumulation and because they partition to the atmosphere where they can 48 
potentially be transported over long distances (e.g. Whelan et al., 2004; Wania, 2006).  49 
One of the most widely used cVMS materials is decamethylcyclopentasiloxane (D5) 50 
which has a range of commercial applications including acting as a carrier ingredient 51 
in some personal care products (e.g. Horii and Kannan, 2008).  Key properties for D5 52 
are summarised in Table 1.  Most D5 which is used in cosmetic products is likely to 53 
be volatilised (Brooke et al., 2008), although some will be sorbed to sewage sludge 54 
during waste water treatment, and subsequently applied to agricultural land.  There 55 
will also be an emission to surface waters in treated effluent.  In the atmosphere, D5 is 56 
expected to break down to silanols by reacting with hydroxyl radicals and is not 57 
expected to partition significantly from the atmosphere to surface media (Wania, 58 
2006), although silanols may be removed from the atmosphere by wet deposition (e.g. 59 
Whelan et al., 2004).  In water, D5 is not biodegradable but does undergo acid- and 60 
base-catalysed hydrolysis.  Estimated hydrolysis half lives derived from experiments 61 
conducted by Dow Corning (cited by Brooke et al., 2008) range from 9 days at pH 8 62 
and 25 °C to 449 days at pH 7 and 9 °C.  D5 does not appear to be toxic to pelagic 63 
organisms at the limit of aqueous solubility (e.g. Hobson et al., 1997).   64 
 65 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
 4 
Although D5 has a very high air : water partition coefficient (KAW), the potential for 66 
volatile losses from rivers may be tempered by interactions with dissolved, colloidal 67 
and suspended material.  Estimating the partition coefficient for D5 between organic 68 
carbon and water (KOC) is, therefore, very important for understanding its 69 
environmental fate.  David et al. (2000) observed significant reductions in the 70 
apparent KAW of D5 measured in simulated waste water using equilibrium partitioning 71 
in closed headspace vials.  They estimated an effective value of log (KOC) of 4.38.  72 
More recently, Whelan et al. (2009) showed a clear inverse relationship between the 73 
rate of volatile loss of D5 and dissolved organic carbon concentration in open beakers 74 
containing mineral medium spiked with Aldrich humic acid (AHA).  By fitting a 75 
simple dynamic partitioning model to the data, Whelan et al. (2009) estimated a mean 76 
effective log (KOC) of 5.28  [log (L kg-1)].   This is very similar to a mean value of log 77 
(KOC) of 5.17  [log (L kg-1)] reported by Durham (2007), obtained from OECD 106 78 
batch equilibrium studies on three different soils.  It is also similar to the molecular 79 
connectivity index estimate of 5.05 implemented in the KOCWIN software (Sabljic, 80 
1987; Meylan et al., 1992).   However, it is much lower than the value of KOC which 81 
might be expected from single parameter linear free energy relationships (LFERs) 82 
between KOC and KOW (e.g. Karickhoff, 1981).  Applying Karickhoff’s relationship 83 
(KOC = 0.41 . KOW) yields a log(KOC) value of 7.66, based on a log(KOW) of 8.05, (i.e. 84 
the most recent industry-derived measured value: Xu and Kozerski, 2007) although 85 
the LFER recommended in EU Technical Guidance (Sabljic et al., 1995; TGD, 2003) 86 
for “predominantly hydrophobic” substances yields a log(KOC) value of 6.6 (Brooke et 87 
al., 2008).   88 
 89 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
 5 
One potential problem with extrapolating the observed behaviour and derived KOC 90 
value reported by Whelan et al. (2009) to the natural environment is that this 91 
experiment was performed using a synthetic medium with AHA.  AHA is a natural 92 
humic acid probably derived from coal (Latch and McNeil, 2006; Malcolm and 93 
MacCarthy, 1986) and differs in quality (and hence sorptive behaviour) from DOC 94 
derived from soils, from aqueous environments and from that found in domestic waste 95 
water (Malcolm and MacCarthy, 1986).  In this paper, we examine the relative 96 
importance of phase partitioning in natural river water using a combination of 97 
laboratory experiment and mathematical modelling. 98 
 99 
Materials and Methods 100 
 101 
Experimental 102 
The experimental system was similar to that described by Whelan et al. (2009).  103 
Briefly, the concentration of 14C -labelled D5 was measured at different time intervals 104 
in open beakers (volume 0.4 L).  Each beaker initially contained 300 mL of liquid.  105 
Six treatments were established, each with three replicates: (1) Millipore water, 106 
stirred; (2) Millipore water, static (unstirred).  (3) River water filtered through a 0.45 107 
µm filter, stirred; (4) River water filtered through a 0.45 µm filter, static; (5) River 108 
water filtered through a 125 µm filter, stirred and (6) River water filtered through a 109 
125 µm filter, static.  In those treatments which were stirred, identical glass-coated 110 
magnetic stirrer bars were used with a multiplace magnetic stirrer in a fume cupboard.  111 
The stirring rate was set at 150 rpm.  River water was collected from the River Nene 112 
(Ditchford, Northamptonshire, UK) approximately 100 meters downstream of the 113 
Broadholme WWTP (which serves approximately 188,000 population equivalents).  114 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
 6 
At this point, the Nene has a mean annual discharge of approximately 4 m3 s-1 (more 115 
than a third of which is derived from treated waste water) and is considered to be 116 
eutrophic (e.g. Balbi, 2000).  It has also been significantly modified for navigation, 117 
principally via the construction of a series of locks.  Further details are decribed in 118 
Balbi (2000), Williams et al. (2003), Jobling et al. (2006) and Sparham et al. (2008). 119 
 120 
Radiolabelled D5 used in the experiment was kindly donated by Dow Corning.  The 121 
material had a specific activity of 120.5 µCi mg-1.  This was used to prepare a dosing 122 
solution by dissolving 10µL in 1 mL of acetonitrile.  The concentration of the dosing 123 
solution was 1.584 mCi mL-1 (13.145 mg mL-1).  Radiochemical purity was estimated 124 
to be ~97%.  As a suitable method for purification was not available at the time the 125 
experiments were conducted, and because of the volatile nature of the test substance, 126 
no purification was attempted.  The impurities were accounted for in the model and 127 
are not believed to affect the interpretation of the data. 128 
 129 
The dosing solution (7µL) was added to the liquid in each beaker using a positive 130 
displacement pipette just under the surface.  All treatments were at room temperature 131 
prior to test item addition.  The experiment was conducted in the artificial light of the 132 
laboratory.  Although this may have resulted in some algal growth, with associated 133 
addition of photosynthetic organic carbon to the system, no such growth was visible 134 
and it is assumed here that photosynthesis was negligible.  Samples were collected 135 
from each beaker at 0, 2, 4, 6, 24, 48 and 72 h after dosing (t0).  At each sampling 136 
event, triplicate 5 mL aliquots were withdrawn (mid vessel) and were counted with 10 137 
mL of Starscint (Perkin Elmer Life Sciences) in a Beckman-Coulter LS6000TA 138 
scintillation counter.  Temperature was observed to be constant throughout the 139 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
 7 
experiment at 25 °C.  The average pH at t0 was 8.01 ± 0.01 and did not change 140 
significantly over the course of the experiment.  At the conclusion of the study, the 141 
contents of each beaker were discarded and the beakers were rinsed with 10 mL of 142 
THF followed by 10 mL of acetonitrile.  Residual radioactivity in rinse solvents was 143 
determined for 5 mL of solvent in 10 mL Starscint.  Residual radioactivity associated 144 
with the glass beaker and stirrer bar at the end of the experiment was always < 1% of 145 
the 14C present at t0 and there was no evidence of any settling out of solid residues 146 
during the experiment.  It was not possible to determine the extent of any association 147 
of 14C with the beaker walls or stirrer bar during the course of the experiment because 148 
no provision was made for sacrificial analysis.  However, this association is assumed 149 
to be minimal. Organic carbon concentration was measured using a Shimadzu TOC-V 150 
total organic carbon (TOC) analyzer.  No characterisation of the organic matter was 151 
attempted.  The nature of the organic matter present will reflect its multiple sources 152 
which include dissolved and particulate losses from soils in the catchment, 153 
autochthonous carbon from in-channel photosynthesis and sewage effluent.  Treated 154 
effluent accounts for approximately 30% of mean river discharge at the sampling 155 
station. 156 
 157 
Model 158 
The behaviour of D5 in the experimental system was described using a dynamic 159 
mathematical model of partitioning and degradation.  The model is based on that 160 
described in detail by Whelan et al. (2009) and was solved numerically.  Only a brief 161 
description is included here.  The total mass of radiolabel in the system (MT) at any 162 
point in time is 163 
 164

generated and MN is the mass of radiolabelled contaminant (initially 3%).  The 169 
radiolabelled contaminant was assumed to be non-volatile based on observations of 170 
residual radioactivity in a number of pilot trials which was approximately consistent 171 
with the level of radiochemical impurity.  172

where z is the water depth (m) and kT (m h-1) is the overall water-air mass transfer 195

where VL is the volume of the liquid phase (which changes over the course of the 209

ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
 10 
KOC values derived from the 0.45 µm-filtered treatments refer, operationally, to 213 
dissolved organic carbon (DOC) : water partitioning (i.e. they are effectively values of 214 
KDOC).  Whilst we recognise that there may be important systematic differences 215 
between KOC and KDOC for many chemicals (e.g. Burkhard, 2000), the limited scope of 216 
our experimental design does not allow these differences to be distinguished for D5. 217 
 218 
Results and Discussion 219 
 220 
The mean measured concentrations of total organic carbon in the 0.45 µm- and 125 221 
µm- filtered river water were 1.3 and 5.1 mg C L-1, respectively.  Mean measured and 222 
best-fit estimates of the 14C remaining in beakers over time are shown in Figure 1 for 223 
stirred treatments and in Figure 2 for static treatments.  In each case (stirred or static), 224 
there is a clear difference between treatments, with significant reductions in the 225 
apparent loss rate in both river water treatments compared with the respective controls 226 
(deionised water).  In all cases, within-treatment variability was generally low.  The 227 
mean coefficient of variability (ratio of measured standard deviation to measured 228 
mean 14C concentration for triplicate samples at each sampling point in each 229 
treatment, averaged by treatment) ranged between 6.1 and 13.5 % in the stirred 230 
treatments and between 2.1 and 6.7 % in the static treatments.  As expected, loss rates 231 
were slower in the static treatments, confirming that volatilisation was the 232 
predominant loss mechanism.  The lowest rate for both the stirred and non stirred 233 
treatments was observed for the 125 µm-filtered river water, which had the highest 234 
organic carbon concentration (5.1 mg C L-1 i.e. almost four times higher than in the 235 
0.45 µm filtered water).  For the 0.45 µm filtered treatments, the increase in apparent 236 
half life compared with the respective control was similar in both the stirred and 237 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
 11 
unstirred systems (at about 2.6 times).  However, there was a much greater difference 238 
in the behaviour of the two river water treatments in the stirred system than in the 239 
static system.  For the 125 µm filtered river water, the apparent half life in the stirred 240 
system was about 8.3 times that in the control, whereas in the unstirred system the 241 
apparent half life was only about 3.3 times greater than in the control.      242 
 243 
The model was able to describe changes in radioactivity in the experimental system 244 
well, particularly in the case of the stirred treatments (Figure 1).  Deviation of model 245 
fit from the experimental data is expressed as the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE).  246 
For the control, the RMSE of the fits was 1.30 for the stirred system and 5.95 % for 247 
the static system.  The RMSE values obtained for the river water treatments are shown 248 
in Table 1.  In the static treatments (Figure 2) the predicted temporal pattern did not 249 
match the observed data for some points (e.g. at 24 hours in the case of the control 250 
and, in the case of the 0.45 µm filtered treatment, in the initial stages of the 251 
experiment and at 72 hours) but overall the match was still reasonable. 252 
Derived values for log (KOC), shown in Table 2, were between 5.8 and 6.33 and were 253 
relatively consistent (mean 6.16; standard deviation 0.25).  There was no apparent 254 
relationship between the value of KOC obtained and the treatment.  The lowest value 255 
was derived for the 125 µm filtered static treatment and the highest for the 0.45 µm 256 
filtered stirred case. 257 
 258 
Two of the main sources of uncertainty in the derived values of KOC are uncertainty in 259 
the measured concentration of TOC and uncertainty in the concentration of 14C 260 
remaining (characterised by the variability in the replicate measurements made in 261 
each treatment).  Since the model is implemented as a numerical solution to series of 262 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
 12 
ordinary differential equations, it is difficult to obtain confidence intervals using 263 
standard statistics without linearization.  Instead, the sensitivity of KOC to the 264 
measured TOC concentration was evaluated by re-optimising the model fits to the 265 
observed radioactivity data (Figures 1 and 2) using 95% confidence limits for the 266 
TOC concentration during fitting (rather than the mean TOC).  The coefficient of 267 
variation for repeat TOC measurements on the same river water was typically in the 268 
range 3 - 6.5%.  A conservative value of 6.5% was assumed here.  The ranges in 269 
resulting values for fitted log (KOC) are shown in Table 2.  Note that using the upper 270 
and lower 95% confidence limits for TOC results in a reduction and increase, 271 
respectively, in the derived KOC relative to using the mean.  However, the results 272 
suggest that the derived value of KOC is relatively insensitive to minor measurement 273 
errors in TOC concentration, typically changing by only about 0.03 log units.   274 
Uncertainty arising from inter-replicate variability in measured 14C concentration was 275 
expressed as 95% confidence intervals for the derived KOC value in each treatment 276 
(Table 2).  These were calculated (using the t-distribution) from standard error 277 
estimates of KOC, obtained from three different model fits on the data from individual 278 
replicates (rather than fitting on the mean values) in each treatment (Whelan et al., 279 
2009).  280 
 281 
In analogous experiments in which changes in radiolabelled D5 concentrations were 282 
measured in an AHA-amended mineral medium (Whelan et al., 2009) the model was 283 
also able to describe concentration changes very well in the initial period of the 284 
experiment.  However, the rate of volatile loss appeared to decrease asymptotically in 285 
all treatments, with an apparent relationship between the asymptote and the organic 286 
carbon concentration in the treatment.  Whelan et al. (2009) invoked a bound-residue 287 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
 13 
hypothesis to explain this phenomenon, based on a hypothetical slowly reversible 288 
absorption of D5 to internal sites within colloids consisting of complex AHA 289 
macromolecules.  In the data described here, such a consistent asymptotic deviation in 290 
loss rate from first order kinetics was not apparent.  This could be due to the shorter 291 
time over which this experiment was conducted (72 hours compared with 120 hours in 292 
the case of the AHA experiment).  However, it could also be due to the nature of the 293 
organic matter present in the respective systems.  This would also provide a 294 
reasonable explanation for differences in the apparent KOC values observed in the two 295 
experiments.  Different types of organic matter are known to exhibit different sorptive 296 
properties and to give different effective values for relevant partition coefficients (e.g. 297 
Gauthier et al., 1987; Raber et al., 1998; Tanaka et al., 2005; Niederer et al., 2007).  298 
For example, significant correlations have been established between increasing KOC 299 
and decreasing polarity index and a reduced number of acidic functional groups 300 
(Tanaka et al., 2005).  Partition coefficients can range over more than one order of 301 
magnitude using organic matter of different origins (Gauthier et al., 1987; Tanaka et 302 
al., 2005).  Terrestrial humic materials often have higher sorption coefficients 303 
compared to organic acids taken from aquatic systems.  Similarly, values of KOC 304 
derived for AHA are often, although not always, reported to be higher than those for 305 
natural dissolved organic matter (e.g. Raber et al., 1998).  However, in the case of 306 
cVMS materials, the type of molecular interactions which take place are known to 307 
differ from many organic chemicals, which is why they possess such unusual 308 
combinations of partitioning properties.  The molecular interactions involved in D5 309 
sorption to organic matter were explored using an Abraham-type poly parameter 310 
LFER.  Such relationships account separately for the contribution of different 311 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
 14 
molecular interactions to the free energy of molecular transfer between two phases 312 
(Abraham, 1993).  They often take the general form for KOC: 313 
 314 
cVvBbAaSsEeKOC +++++= .....log      (6) 315 
 316 
where c is a constant, e, s, a, b and v are matrix-specific parameters, which depend on 317 
the difference in chemical properties between organic carbon and water (Nguyen et 318 
al., 2005) and where E, S, A, B and V are so-called solute descriptors, which quantify 319 
the capacity for specific intermolecular interactions.  Specifically, they refer to excess 320 
molar refraction (E), dipole-dipole interaction (S), hydrogen-bond acidity (A), 321 
hydrogen-bond basicity (B) and characteristic volume (V).  Matrix descriptors for KOC 322 
have been derived empirically by Nguyen et al. (2005) using 356 measured KOC 323 
values for 75 chemicals in a range of soils and sediments.  Nguyen et al. (2005) also 324 
report regression parameters for KOW.   Solute descriptors have been determined 325 
independently for siloxanes, including D5, by Ahmed et al. (2007) using a range of 326 
techniques, including gas chromatography and liquid-liquid partitioning.  The above 327 
parameters, together with derived values of log(KOC) and log(KOW) for D5 are shown 328 
in Table 3.  The derived values for log(KOC) and log(KOW) were 5.5 and 7.75, 329 
respectively.  They suggest that the ppLFER is a reasonable predictor of log(KOC) 330 
compared with the measured values reported by Durham (2007) and Whelan et al. 331 
(2009).  However, this value is somewhat lower than the values of KOC derived from 332 
the experiments reported in this paper.  There is also a discrepancy between the 333 
ppLFER-derived value of log(KOW) and the observed value of 8.05 reported by Xu 334 
and Kozerski (2007).  Without an independent measurement of KOW it is not possible 335 
to comment further on the validity of this estimate.  The solute descriptors shown in 336 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
 15 
Table 3 (Ahmed et al., 2007) suggest that D5 has negative excess molar refraction (E) 337 
and near zero polarizability (S) but relatively high characteristic volume (V) and 338 
hydrogen bond basicity (B).  These features might explain the lower apparent affinity 339 
of D5 for AHA compared with the organic matter in water collected from the River 340 
Nene, which has mixed origins and which has a relatively high fraction of treated 341 
waste water effluent, if phase descriptors for AHA and river water organic matter 342 
were to be determined.  In any case, additional empirical work is needed to 343 
understand differences in partitioning behaviour for D5 and other cVMS materials, 344 
with different types of organic matter in the natural environment. 345 
 346 
 347 
Implications for Environmental Behaviour 348 
 349 
The implications of different effective values of KOC derived from different 350 
experiments for the fate of D5 in river water were explored using an extension of the 351 
model described above.  The model was solved to yield changes in D5 concentration 352 
for time-of-travel (i.e. the quotient of river distance and velocity) in a 2 m deep river 353 
over 96 hours.  This corresponds to a distance of 138 km, based on a mean solute 354 
velocity of 0.4 ms-1, which is representative of river lengths in the UK.  Three 355 
different TOC concentrations (1, 5 and 10 mg C L-1) were considered with two values 356 
of log(KOC): 5.28 (after Whelan et al., 2009) and 6.16 (the mean value derived here).  357 
The range of TOC concentrations is typical of the range reported in British rivers (e.g. 358 
Worrall et al., 2004).  Equilibrium partitioning between the freely dissolved and 359 
sorbed (suspended solid, colloidal and dissolved organic carbon fractions) phases was 360 
assumed.  No D5 exchanges between the bed and banks of the river and the water 361 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
 16 
column were considered.  This is reasonable if the system is in steady state, such that 362 
the bed material is in equilibrium with the water column (Schwarzenbach et al., 363 
2003).  Whilst rivers clearly experience transient conditions during storm events, 364 
under normal and low flows the steady state assumption is a valid one for chemicals 365 
discharged continuously via waste water (Whelan et al., 1999; Facchi et al., 2007).  366 
Values for the partial mass transfer coefficients in the two-film resistance model for 367 
volatilisation (e.g. Mackay, 2001) were set at 0.05 and 5 m h-1, respectively, for the 368 
water (kW) and air (kA) sides, as recommended in EU Technical Guidance (TGD, 369 
2003).  Again, it should be noted that for such a high value of KAW, the value of kA has 370 
no influence on the rate of volatilisation.  A hydrolysis half life of 64 d was assumed 371 
for dissolved phase D5 (representing pH 8 and 9 °C).  Over the four-day time-of-372 
travel considered here, hydrolysis was always a relatively unimportant contributor to 373 
D5 losses (< 4%), even in the absence of organic carbon. 374 
 375 
Changes in the predicted concentration of D5 in river water with time-of-travel are 376 
shown in Figure 3.  With no organic carbon in the water, the loss of D5 is relatively 377 
rapid with a dissipation half life of 27.7 h.  However, with increasing TOC 378 
concentrations, the rate of volatile loss decreases, particularly if a high value is 379 
assumed for KOC.  The effective half lives for the high KOC scenario were factors of 380 
2.07, 4.38 and 5.79 higher than for the low KOC scenario for 1, 5 and 10 mg C L-1, 381 
respectively, given an equivalent TOC concentration.  Volatilisation was predicted to 382 
reduce D5 concentrations by 63, 25 and 13%, respectively for TOC concentrations of 383 
1, 5 and 10 mg C L-1, in the high KOC scenario over a four day time-of-travel.  384 
However, it should be noted that in real rivers concentration changes are likely to be 385 
influenced by river discharge and depth variations (spatial and temporal) and by 386 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
 17 
changes in turbulence (which will affect gas exchange), as well as by various 387 
emissions from waste water treatment plants along the length of the river.  It should 388 
also be noted that KOC is likely to be temperature dependent.  Unpublished data from 389 
Dow Corning suggest that there is a positive relationship between KOW and 390 
temperature (positive enthalpy of phase change).  It is expected, therefore, that the 391 
effective environmental KOC value will, in fact, be lower than that implied by the 392 
experimental data reported here since, except for the tropics, river water temperatures 393 
are likely to be lower than 25 °C.  Additional empirical work is needed to verify the 394 
river predictions reported here, which should include a study to measure changes in 395 
concentration in the same mass of water with time of travel (e.g. employing dye 396 
tracing) similar to that described by Whelan et al. (2007) for Linear Alkylbenzene 397 
Sulphonate. 398 
 399 
 400 
Conclusions 401 
   402 
• A simple model was used to describe observed changes in the concentration of 403 
radiolabelled decamethylcyclopentasiloxane (D5) in open beakers containing 404 
deionised and river water.   405 
• Values for the effective log partition coefficient between organic carbon and 406 
water [log(KOC)] were estimated, via model optimisation, to range between 5.8 407 
and 6.33, with an average value of 6.12 log(L kg-1).   408 
• The model was extrapolated to predict D5 behaviour in an idealised river 409 
reach under steady state conditions with different concentrations of TOC and 410 
assuming different values of KOC.  The results suggest that although the rate of 411 
M
AN
US
CR
IP
T
 
AC
CE
PT
ED
ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT
 18 
volatilisation is retarded by higher values of KOC, water-air transfer is still 412 
likely to make a significant (>50%) contribution to concentration changes of 413 
D5 over typical solute travel times in relatively shallow river reaches with low, 414 
but realistic, TOC concentrations.  415 
• Additional work is required to quantify the affinity of D5 for natural organic 416 
matter of different origins and to develop a mechanistic understanding of any 417 
differences observed.   418
